oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Low and high input agricultural fields have different effects on pest aphid abundance via different invasive alien weed species
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Szabó, Attila-Károly
Kiss, József
Bálint, János
Kőszeghi, Szidónia
Loxdale, Hugh D.
Balog, Adalbert
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: invasive species
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: <jats:p>We conducted field surveys to detect the population density of the most important invasive weed species and their associated virus vectoring aphids in crops grown under high input field (HIF) vs low-input field (LIF) conditions, with and without fertilizers and pesticides. The most frequent invasive weed species were <jats:italic>Stenactisannua</jats:italic>, <jats:italic>Erigeroncanadensis</jats:italic> and <jats:italic>Solidagocanadensis</jats:italic>. These species were hosts predominantly for the aphids <jats:italic>Brachycaudushelichrysi</jats:italic> and <jats:italic>Aulacorthumsolani</jats:italic> in both management systems. The 13% higher coverage of <jats:italic>S.annua</jats:italic> under LIF conditions resulted in a 30% higher <jats:italic>B.helichrysi</jats:italic> abundance and ~85% higher <jats:italic>A.solani</jats:italic> abundance compared with HIF conditions. Host plant quality was assessed by measuring peroxidase enzyme activity. There was a significantly increased POD activity at 10 μmol min<jats:sup>−1</jats:sup> mg protein<jats:sup>−1</jats:sup> unit in <jats:italic>S.annua</jats:italic> under LIF conditions, suggesting a higher stress by aphids under this management regime. The high colonization intensity of <jats:italic>B.helichrysi</jats:italic> on maize, potato and alfalfa crops were detected from both <jats:italic>S.annua</jats:italic> and <jats:italic>E.canadensis</jats:italic>. We conclude that new and faster methods need to be used to prevent colonization of such virus vectoring aphids and their host plants, even under low input regimes.</jats:p>
